values: Once upon a time I was (even more) jaded and cynical- not to mention bitterly sarcastic(see an example here). Just like a razor: sharp, cold and tearing things apart. And kids who play with sharp objects end up hurting themselves. I didn't care. Everything was bleak, but razors are shinny. The world was mean, and razors were for my own protection. I really miss those days. But, somewhere along the way, colours and sounds began to sneak on me. And, my life became a fucking technicolour stereo sound musical picture- complete with cheesy songs, dazzling routines and dozens of extras. Now, that was scary. It still is. I miss being in that grey phase between "puppy love"(and pretty insignificant crushes) and "discovering true love for the first time". It was easier to be cynical- just say " been there, done that", and keep on trucking, never expecting much more. Once upon a time I tried to believe in a simple straight-forward life plan (with a lot of consumerist fantasies). Stability and Focus were supposed to bring happiness. All the rest was supperfluous: including the present moment, the past, personal ethics, and any sub- conscious urges. They called it "growing up". For me it was more like "giving up". I swear I tried.

I probably got home around 10:30pm last night. 
All the lights were off. The security chain was in place. My parent's bedroom door was closed. My computer was on. 
My logical assumption: My parents are asleep. 

Around midnight, as I was getting ready to go to bed, I hear my parents calling me. 
And they were...upset... at me. 
Why? 
Because I was home. 
Exactly. 

If I don't sleep at home,if it's late, if I don't call, if I stumble home drunk... But this is the first time they got upset because I was home. 

And then, they proceeded to actualy say" Why didn't you turn all the lights on?". Uh, because it costs money to have lights on when you are not using then? 

(Actually- my dad left to pick up my mom at the subway station. I got home while he was gone, and went to my bedroom. They got home, and only realized I was there when I made some noise ). 

Maybe I've become a silent Ninja.

I saw "Che" today. A movie about Ernesto Che Guevara (I'll probably post more about it later). 

Then, I was talking about it with my parents.
My dad, of course, decided to play devil's advocate by adopting a right-wing point of view. 
My Mom, on the other hand, said something like this: "I thank God that we are not in the 60's anymore. I'd be worried sick about you!" And she REALLY meant it. 
Awwwwww Mom.

1. Life would be so much better with " comics/old movie style " sound effects. 

2. A consistent plotline makes a show much better.  I'm comparing " Saltimbanco"  to " Kooza" , another Cirque du Solei show. " Kooza"  had a consistent, well developed, clear plotline; while " Saltimbanco"  either didn't have a plotline, or it was very weak. But maybe I'm just being a dumb foreigner, since Wikipedia tells me there is a plotline in " Saltimbanco" . 

3. Re-occuring characters draw the audience attention. And the use of easily identifiable characters(archetypes/stock characters) can be a marvelous thing, since you don't have to " spend precious time" establishing " a character.  

4.(Spoken) Language. You don't really need it. 

5. If you can't lift the fat man, tickle him. 


PS: What's the point of paying a lot of money to see a show, arriving late, getting up (in the middle of the show) to buy expensive crappy food, and then leaving early? No, I didn't do that, but a LOT of people in the audience did.

10 things I learned from.... Pride '08

1) People will line up for the same club/bars/restaurants they go every week. Go figure! 

2)You(ME!) probably will appear in photos taken by people you don't know. And then, people that do know you will tag you in the photos -on facebook. Next year I'll dress up as Waldo. 

3) Forget about watching the actual parade. March in the parade, and then observe the crowd- it's so much more fun! 

4) The best place to "watch" the parade is: either at the very beggining, or at the very end (well, before the floats and the marchers part ways). 

5) Pride is a great place for flyering/giving out things. People will grab just about anything they can. Dental floss? Sure! Buttons agains malaria? Why not! 

6)No matter what you do, you will end up with a weird tan. Glasses, sandals,even facial hair,  etc

7) Pride Toronto is quite...un-unified.  

8)Sleep? Who needs sleep? It's PRIDE! 
I swear, it has something to do with the "gay gene". I have a quite scientific explanation for it: The rising temperatures activate the special PRIDE section of the gay gene. Then, all the queers begin to produce the fab pheromone- which makes us all begin to plan , in detail: hair, clothes, and which events to attend. Since it's a "folie a plusieurs", almost a mass hysteria, you can't really scape it. Then, on the actual pride weekend...well, it all works on the basis of "positive reinforcement": the gays see the rainbow, and automatically:1) Adrenaline rush 2)"Forget" about sleeping 3)Buy alcohol, and junk food from the vendors 4) Say "happy pride!" to everyone 5)"There isn't enough people here, let's go to somewhere more crowded"
( Seriously, couldn't "we" spread out the events through out the year? )

9) You will run into people that were part of "different stages of your queer life". And the best way out is to say....yes..."Happy pride!". 

10) There is nothing like "counting down" the minutes to midnight on Sunday. Aloud, on the corner of Carlton and Church. And then, hugging each other saying "Yeeeeeeeeeah, we are straight!!!!Pride is over!!!". Other good thing is...walking up church st while they are taking things down. But the best-est thing is being on a patio on church st, a few days after Pride, and thinking- I can actually SEE the ground, I can actually even hear myself thinking!

This thursday I received the "Youthline Awards for outsdanding contribution to art and leadership". I was nominated by a person that I don't like that much, and from start the whole idea seemed a bit....weird: "You want to nominate me? Suuuuuuure, do that, but I doubt they will choose me". 
I was wrong, wasn't I? 
Part of the "weirdness" feeling was knowing that so many other people do so much more for the community, and have much more interesting lives....and still, were not nominated/chosen. 

The whole thing went well. I managed not to feel terribly akward or pathologically shy. Having friends and people that I like there helped a lot! I delivered my speech- nothing spetacular- but public speaking is still nerve-wrecking for me sometimes. The food was good.The money was good(maybe I'll put it into making my next short!). Then, we went for coffee. Very quiet, but a good night after all. 


Oh, so, I didn't invite my parents to the ceremony. First, they had to work. Second, I decided to use 'Luka" as my name for the award. And I really didn't  want to explain anything to them. However, I did tell them about it the day after. They have seen the program for the evening, and the plaque, and they haven't said anything about the name. A bit unusual for them, but i'm not complaining.

Toronto is supposed to be a big city. A big, mean, annonymous city. 

It's not THAT big- well, at least the downtown core is not (yes, i'm comparing it to Sao Paulo). 

It's not THAT mean. The crime rates are certainly going up,but I still feel pretty safe. Maybe I shouldn't feel so safe, but what can you do when you grew up in a city(yes, Sao Paulo)where kidnappings and pickpocketing are extremely common? Oh well. 

And, Toronto is definitly NOT annonymous. I'm not " popular" or " cool" , I'm socially akward, I didn't grow up here. Damn, I didn't even leave the house that much two years ago! However, no matter where I go, I'm sure to " bump"  into someone that I " sort of"  know. 

Weird. Akward. Mainly, because I'm terrible with names and small talk. No, I'm not terrible...I pratically go into " panic mode"  when I have to make conversation with someone that I barely know. 

Last saturday I went (alone) to a " no one is illegal"  rally. There were 4 people that I knew there, which was ok. I don't mind saying " Hi"  from afar. 
I do like to " bump" into some people from time to time, and have brief nice conversations about random things.

But then, this girl approached me. She knew me, but I didn't know her. She saw me performing at Queer cab ( in drag, performing to " detachable penis" ). And she WANTED to talk...and talk...and talk...about NOTHING. Akward. 

Something was weird in the whole encouter.I do like when people " recognize" me. I'm definitly not ashamed of my performances (ok, maybe I do blush a little when people mention them). It's nice to realize that I do " know" quite a few people. And, It's even nicer to have friends(yes, I do sound like a dork!)

But...do I actually have to make small talk with people? Can't we just jump right ahead into: a)deep philosophical conversations about random and/or trivial matters that we are both obcessed with b)sarcastic/funny/silly/gossip-y conversations c)making out. 

I was going to rant about " community" ....but I'll do that some other day!

So, I decided to re-start writing on my livejournal. After serve! I miss journal writing, and 1) I'm online all-day 2)I'm trying to use as little paper as I can. 

So, I'll start with a "Brutally honest"personal ad: 

Being brutally honest:25 yrs old, still living at home and broke. Strong accent, speak broken english once in a while- you must be patient and NEVER doubt my intelligence. Shy, socially akward and terribly afraid of the telephone( I probably won't call you back). Very Sarcastic, dark sense of humour, and not exactly politically correct. Internet addict. Unorganized and a procrastinator. Very good memory- I tend to spook people when I remember details about their lives, but I'm not nosy( I swear!). I can't dance, drive or play any sport. Plus, I don't have a fashion sense. I love books, history, unpractical philosophical discussions, movies (no dumb comedies or action flicks!), theater, photography and writing. You should like going to readings, performances, sketchy/bad plays and galleries. I know nothing about music- I probably never heard about your favourite band.
You must be confortable with your sexuality. I'm not exactly a monogamous person. 
You should not be transphobic, racist or a xenophobe.
